questions.question:
Question 1: A 35-year-old lady presents with pulmonary TB is started on anti-tubercular therapy. What is 
the rationale for administering multi-drug therapy to her?

options.d: To prevent toxin release from the organism

questions.explanation:
The reason for administering multi-drug therapy in tuberculosis is to prevent the development of 
resistance. Resistance to individual drugs in Mycobacterium tuberculosis occurs by spontaneous point 
mutations that occur at a low but predictable rate (10-7 to 10-10 ). Development of this drug 
resistance is almost invariably the result of monotherapy, i.e., the failure of the health care 
provider to prescribe at least 2 drugs to which the tubercle bacilli are susceptible. Hence, 
multi-drug therapy is recommended for the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the most effective drug against extracellular mycobacteria?
questions.explanation:
The most effective drug against extracellular mycobacteria is Rifampicin. 567 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Isoniazid and Rifampicin act against both intracellular and 
extracellular mycobacterium. But, Rifampicin inhibits the extracellular mycobacteria at much 
lower drug concentrations than isoniazid. Option B: Pyrazinamide acts only against intracellular mycobacterium. Option C: Ethambutol acts against only extracellular mycobacteria but is not as effective as 
rifampicin. It is a bacteriostatic drug. Fast-multiplying bacteria are highly susceptible to its 
action. Note: Streptomycin is primarily active against only the extracellular tubercle bacilli as its 
penetration into the cells is very poor.

questions.question:
Question 3: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line 
antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the 
marked layer shown in the image? 560 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid. Isoniazid is a first-line bactericidal drug that is used for the treatment of tuberculosis. This drug 
enters bacilli by passive diffusion. It then gets activated to its toxic form by the enzyme 
catalase-peroxidase(the enzyme encoded by the Kat gene). Normally, InhA and KasA are involved in the synthesis of mycolic acid. Upon activation, the 
reactive metabolite of isoniazid forms complexes with NAD that inhibit InhA and KasA. Hence, 
isoniazid inhibits the production of mycolic acid. The reactive isoniazid metabolite also forms complexes with NADP. This complex inhibits 
mycobacterial dihydrofolate reductase which results in the interruption of DNA synthesis. Side effects of isoniazid include: • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal 
phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically 
along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity. • Hepatitis - isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity. • Rashes • Anaemia • Arthralgia Toxicity of isoniazid results in metabolic acidosis, seizures, and coma. Other options: Option B: Rifampin acts by binding to DNA-dependent RNA polymerase to form a stable 
drug-enzyme complex. This complex suppresses RNA synthesis. Side effects of rifampin are 
hepatitis, flu-like illness, orange-red colored urine, and body secretions. Option C: Pyrazinamide is a prodrug, it is converted into an active metabolite pyrazinoic acid 
which makes the intracellular environment acidic and collapses the transmembrane proton 
motive force, thereby killing the bacteria. Side effects include hyperuricemia and hepatotoxicity. Option D: Ethambutol inhibits arabinose transferase III, thereby decreasing arabinogalactan 
biosynthesis. This results in disruption in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. Optic neuritis is an 568 
Sold by @itachibot important side effect of ethambutol. It results in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green 
discrimination.

questions.question:
Question 4: A study was conducted to genotype NAT2 gene polymorphisms in patients receiving ATT. 
Among the 300 patients genotyped, 200 were slow acetylators (group A), 70 were 
intermediate (group B) and 30 were fast acetylators (group C). Patients in group A are prone 
to develop which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Isoniazid, a key agent in the ATT, is metabolized primarily through N-acetylation by the 
genetically polymorphic N-acetyltransferase-2 (NAT2) enzyme. Slow acetylators (group A) of 
isoniazid are prone to develop peripheral neuropathy. The rate of metabolism of isoniazid is determined by the genetic polymorphism of NAT2 enzyme 
and classified broadly into two groups - slow and fast acetylators. In slow acetylators, the drug accumulates due to slow metabolism resulting in an increased risk 
of side effects, and hence they should undergo periodic monitoring. Peripheral neuropathy is a 
more frequent side effect of INH when compared to hepatotoxicity. Fast acetylators metabolize the drug rapidly and show less response to standard doses and the 
therapy may be less effective.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 4-month-old boy was brought to the ER with recurrent seizures. His mother informs you 
that he is receiving isoniazid prophylaxis as she was diagnosed with TB during pregnancy. 
ABG revealed a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. What would be the mainstay of treatment?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of isoniazid overdose for which the mainstay of treatment 
is intravenous pyridoxine. Isoniazid overdose results in decreased pyridoxine availability to neurons. This decreases the 
levels of GABA, which in turn lowers the seizure threshold. Benzodiazepines can be used to 569 
Sold by @itachibot control seizures. Prolonged treatment with isoniazid leads to the deficiency of pyridoxine which can lead to 
peripheral neuropathy and other neurological manifestations like ataxia, paresthesia, and 
numbness. Clinical triad of isoniazid overdose: • Seizures refractory to treatment with phenytoin and barbiturates • High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) resistant to treatment with sodium bicarbonate • Coma

questions.question:
Question 7: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for follow-up. His wife states 
that recently he is forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects 
them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss. Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with 
isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like: • Euphoria • Transient memory loss • Separation of ideas and reality • Loss of self-control • Florid psychosis Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental 
abnormalities.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 66-year-old woman, on anti-tubercular therapy, presented with pain in the right hand and 
shoulder for the past 1 month. On physical examination, her wrist was swollen and her 
shoulder was extremely painful with a limited range of motion. Which drug is most likely 
associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical presentation is suggestive of shoulder-hand syndrome which is associated with 
the use of isoniazid. This syndrome is characterized by painful arthropathy in the upper extremity joints. It can also 
present as generalized arthropathy. Other drugs that can cause shoulder-hand syndrome are phenobarbitone and phenytoin.

questions.question:
Question 9: 562 
Sold by @itachibot Before initiating treatment for a sputum-positive TB patient, the physician orders for 
Cartridge Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test in order to test for drug resistance. Which 
anti-tubercular drug resistance is he checking for?
questions.explanation:
The Cartridge Based-Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT) is a molecular test for 
tuberculosis that detects the DNA of tubercle bacilli within 2 hours and mutations in the rpoB 
gene responsible for rifampicin resistance. 570 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following rifamycin drugs would you advise a patient to take on an empty 
stomach?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin should be advised to be taken on an empty stomach because food decreases its 
absorption. Rifabutin absorption is not altered by food. Rifapentine absorption is enhanced by fatty food and hence it is recommended to be taken with 
food.

questions.question:
Question 11: An HIV-positive patient on ART with zidovudine, lamivudine, and indinavir develops 
pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following anti-tubercular drugs should be avoided in 
him?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin should be avoided as it is a potent inducer of CYP enzymes including CYPs 1A2, 3A4, 
2C9, and 2C19, which in turn can induce the metabolism of indinavir and results in therapeutic 
failure of ART. Rifabutin causes the least induction of cytochrome enzymes and is therefore preferred in HIV 
patients who are on protease inhibitors/NNRTIs. Cytochrome enzyme-inducing potency of rifamycins is: rifampicin > rifapentine > rifabutin. Note: Cytochrome p-450 inducers

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following rifamycins is not used for mycobacterial infections?
questions.explanation:
Rifaximin is not used for mycobacterial infections. It is a synthetic rifamycin that is poorly 
absorbed from the GIT and is indicated in the management of GI conditions like: • Traveler’s diarrhea • Irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea • Hepatic encephalopathy Rifamycins indicated in mycobacterial infections are rifampicin, rifapentine, and rifabutin.

questions.question:
Question 13: A Gene Xpert test was conducted on the sputum sample of a patient with suspected TB. The 
results were positive and showed resistance to rifampicin. What is the primary mechanism of 
resistance against this drug?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin resistance is primarily due to alteration in the target enzyme. 571 
Sold by @itachibot Rifampicin acts by binding to the  subunit of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (rpoB) and 
inhibits chain formation in RNA synthesis. Rifampicin is a potent inducer of cytochrome 
enzymes CYP3A4, CYP1A2, CYP2C9, and CYP2C19. Alteration of the target enzyme (rpoB) by a 
mutation in the gene coding for rpoB is the primary mechanism of resistance to rifampicin. Gene 
Xpert identifies mutations in the rpoB gene to detect rifampicin resistance. Efflux pump induction has also been demonstrated as a mechanism of rifampicin resistance.

questions.question: Question 14: In which of the following conditions can rifampicin be used?
questions.explanation:
Besides its anti-tubercular action, rifampicin also has certain non-tubercular uses which include: • Prophylaxis of meningococcal and H. influenzae meningitis • Treatment of MRSA, diphtheroid, and legionella infections • Eradication of staphylococcal nasal carrier state in patients with chronic furunculosis • A combination of doxycycline and rifampicin is used as the first-line therapy for brucellosis • A part of the WHO regimen for standard therapy of both paucibacillary and 
multibacillary leprosy Rifampicin is not used in the treatment of Nocardia species. Cotrimoxazole is considered the drug 
of choice for pleuropulmonary nocardiosis.

questions.question:
Question 15: You are prescribing first-line anti-tubercular therapy to a patient newly diagnosed with TB. 
Which of the following is incorrect about his therapy?

options.a: Red green color impairment is an early sign of ethambutol induced optic neuritis
options.c: Flu-like syndrome is usually seen if rifampicin is taken on a daily basis
options.d: Hyperuricemia is a recognised side effect of pyrazinamide

questions.explanation:
Flu-like syndrome is usually seen when rifampicin is administered less than twice weekly (high 
dose) and it is uncommon when administered daily (lower dose). Flu-like syndrome, characterized by fevers, chills, malaise, and arthralgia is a known 
dose-dependent adverse effect of rifampicin therapy and tends to occur late into the patient's 
treatment course. It resolves with either discontinuation of rifampin or switching to a daily-dose 
regimen. It can often be confused with occult infections or treatment failure. Options A and B: Red-green colour impairment is one of the early signs of ethambutol-induced 
optic neuritis. Ethambutol is primarily excreted unchanged by kidneys and accumulation occurs 
in renal failure. Ethambutol does not undergo hepatic metabolism and can be safely prescribed 
for the treatment of TB in patients with hepatitis. Option D: Pyrazinamide interferes with urate excretion and can result in hyperuricemia.

questions.question:
Question 16: A young woman undergoing treatment for tuberculosis visits your OPD for a routine checkup. 
She informs you that recently she has noticed an orange-colored discoloration of her contact 
lenses. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin is the drug most likely to cause orange-colored discoloration of contact lenses in this 
case. 572 
Sold by @itachibot Drugs like rifampicin and rifabutin are known to cause reddish-orange discoloration of the skin, 
urine, feces, saliva, sweat, and tears (which can stain the patient's contact lenses).

questions.question:
Question 17: You are planning to start treatment in a middle-aged man diagnosed with pulmonary 
tuberculosis. He has a history of chronic kidney disease and his current creatinine clearance 
is 25 mL/min. Which of the following drugs is least likely to require dose modification?
questions.explanation:
Rifampicin is the least likely drug to require dose modification in renal failure patients as it is 
metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted in bile. In patients with renal failure, the half-life of isoniazid will be prolonged, but its adverse effects are 
not significantly increased. Hence dose modification is not usually done for isoniazid in clinical 
practice as a reduction in dose may render the regimen ineffective and increase the chances of 
resistance. Ethambutol and streptomycin are primarily excreted unchanged through the renal system and 
need dose modification in renal failure.

questions.question: Question 18: Pseudojaundice is an adverse effect of which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation: Pseudojaundice is an adverse effect of rifabutin. It resolves on discontinuation of the drug. Unique adverse effects of rifabutin are: • Polymyalgia/arthralgia • Pseudojaundice • Anterior uveitis

questions.question:
Question 19: Mycobacterium tuberculosis nicotinamidase is involved in the activation of which of the 
following antitubercular drug?
questions.explanation:
Mycobacterium tuberculosis nicotinamidase is involved in the activation of pyrazinamide. Nicotinamidase which is produced by M. tuberculosis is also called pyrazinamidase. It is encoded 
by the pncA gene and its mutations are associated with pyrazinamide resistance. It converts 
pyrazinamide to active pyrazinoic acid. Pyrazinoic acid has the following actions: • Inhibition of fatty acid synthetase type 1 leads to interference in mycolic acid synthesis • Reduction of intracellular pH • Disruption of membrane transport

questions.question:
Question 20: 565 
Sold by @itachibot A 47-year-old man on treatment for TB presents with complaints of severe pain and swelling 
in his left great toe since today morning, as shown in the image below. Which of the following 
drugs is most likely to cause this?
questions.explanation:
573 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical history and findings of first metatarsophalangeal joint swelling are suggestive of 
an acute episode of gout. Antitubercular drugs that are most likely to cause hyperuricemia and 
precipitate gout are pyrazinamide and ethambutol. Both pyrazinamide and ethambutol inhibit uric acid excretion in the kidney causing 
hyperuricemia.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 33-year-old woman receiving treatment for TB presents to your OPD with complaints of 
blurry vision and pain on movement of the left eye for the past 2 days. Examination showed 
Marcus Gunn pupil. Which anti-tubercular drug is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with Marcus Gunn pupil are suggestive of optic neuritis, which is 
a dose-dependent adverse effect associated with ethambutol. Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of red-green discrimination is the most 
serious adverse effect of ethambutol. It can be unilateral or bilateral and usually recovers when 
the drug is stopped. Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically 
thereafter are recommended. 574 
Sold by @itachibot Second Line Drugs for Tuberculosis
